This article is one example of sports writers not waiting and spending more time around a story. First, several members of the White Sox told management they were uncomfortable having a 14 year old kid always in the clubhouse, even in meetings. Second, LaRoche blowtorched Williams, Reinsdorf, White Sox management, and a result, his own teammates with his entitled self-absorption.

Don't agree? This is from one of the top beat writers covering the Chisox. Read and understand LaRoche's skewed, entitled perspective: http://www.dailyherald.com/article/20160319/sports/160318552/?utm_source...

All of you holier-than-thou commenters are missing one crucial point: Williams lied to everyone, telling players the coaches were to blame, telling coaches was the players, and telling the press is was the owner. If LaRoche used time with his kid as a condition in his contract, he has every right. If he felt that condition was unfairly revoked, he has every right as well to retire (or sue, which he decided not to do).

How many here ignore the ham-fisted way Williams handled this situation, and readily pass judgment on LaRoche's parenting skills, is beyond my keen.

Golden States presents as playing smarter than the other guys. Not last night; Boris Diaw was in the house, and when, as in the case now, he is fit, he elevates the Spurs to a whole other level.

All I've read and heard from the experts was Aldridge and Leonard. All I know is is that, without Diaw,had no chance. The defense was superb, but it was the Spurs ability to get what they wanted on offense, to create easy chances in the half court off multiple passes, unscripted riffs off a schematic, impossible to game for, that beat Golden State at its own game. It just might be that what we we saw last night is what Pop has decided to go with.

If so, it will be a work in progress, and all the taking thus far becomes irrelevant. Next play.
Twice as many three point shots were taken in the game compared with the typical game in 2000.  Three point shooting has changed the game so much that no game today resembles any game 20 years ago.

This game was an example of  late 90s/early 2000s basketball at its finest. The Spurs have realized that they only way to beat Golden State is to force them to play slow, grind-it-out and pound-it-inside basketball, combined with stifling anti-Curry perimeter defense. They will never blow out the Warriors that way, but they will make every game close. Aldridge is just too big for small-ball. If these two teams meet in the playoffs it will be a series for the ages.
A great game but both teams can loose to the other and still be good.

Regular season wins in the NBA are often tainted.  Playing a team in the second game of a back to back, when they're in the middle of a long road trip, or when their stars are sitting for minor injuries gives you an advantage.  This cuts both ways, off course.  But setting the record for regular season wins is not nearly as meaningful nor as important as winning in the playoffs.  Playoff basketball is a lot more intense than regular season games. Winning in the regular season is a sign that you excel when everybody is going 75%.  The Warriors are surely much more intent on winning the championship than beating the 1995-96 Bulls.

When I was young (born in 1945), America was indeed "the greatest country in the world" - at least for people like myself. I went to excellent public schools with lots of other middle income - not rich - kids. I had student loans in college, but the federal government paid for much of my graduate education in political science and Asian Studies. The economy and the plentitude of decent jobs made it possible to choose rather than just settle for things in our lives, and the intellectual and cultural atmosphere was serious, not trivial, due to the debate over the Vietnam War and the Civil Rights Movement - not to mention the earliest stages of feminism.

All of these things I was very lucky to experience. But now we live in the age of economic insecurity, political theocracy, Trump and Cruz. Etc. Everything nowadays is either dangerous or trivial. But given the benefits of being an American in my youth, I feel I have some obligation to stick it out in the States while we all go to hell in a hand basket.

Then again, if Ted "Torquemada" Cruz becomes President . . . well, that will be a real test!
Oh, they'd better not! We'd have a riot - sorry, protest - and push 'em into the ocean!

Ian,

So, in your book, he's a Jew by proxy and that's a good thing? That's a terrible way to like or dislike people... You know, the stuff about judging people by their character Martin Luther King talked about?

But that might actually backfire on the GOP since Trump's fanatical followers are dumb enough to believe that when Bernie says "Let them eat cake" he's actually referring to cake in the Betty Crocker sense of the term.

Conservative pundits live in a bubble of their own, just like pundits on the left. The difference is that they've come to the end of what they can do to keep the con going. The base no longer buys what they have to sell and Paul Ryan is the establishment.

Donald Trump very artfully found a way to repackage the con formula to his advantage. The idea of grabbing back all the loot Trump says the Chinese, Mexicans, Vietnamese, Japanese and others supposedly took from us is very alluring to jobless, underemployed, angry conservative members of the base. I am surprised pundits, on any side, has picked up on The Donald's promise to install Carl Icahn as his trade negotiator. Whose interests would he serve? We should be talking about who really took the loot and how trade agreements in recent decades have benefited a certain circle of robber barons.

Sound familiar? Yep! That's what Bernie talks about! without talking about grab, grab, grab... This, among many other reasons, is why he resonates to so many, including conservatives voters who won't vote for either Trump or Hillary and millions of Democrats who chose Bernie over Hillary in primaries which, by the way, we still are only halfway through.

We need to talk about the things voters care about: the precarious situation so many are in that pundits stopped talking about, and how it gets better.

"We have learned what conditions make the prime environment for the rise of a demagogue: disaffection, demographic change, the demise of hope and opportunity and the dislocation of traditional power and privilege from automatic inheritance of prosperity."

Easy for you to say, Charles. Your peers made the real estate developer as they were doing their best to foil the boy from Brooklyn. Now, as we are at the halfway point of the election cycle and your peers insist on the victorious outcome of the presumptive queen, an image is emerging of a disaffected part of the Republican electorate that sees the queen in the same light as the Republican establishment and, in the absence of an acceptable Republican nominee, will trust Bernie Sanders more than Hillary Clinton.

As you pointed out last week, the media bias against Bernie Sanders has been more than apparent, including this paper's strange editing and eventual transformation of a piece on Sanders from positive to its polar opposite, over the objections of readers who noticed.

But the Times has hardly been alone in its dereliction of journalistic duty. So, along all the things you write about that we learned, we are also learning to disconnect from traditional media and going to trusted sources for news and analysis.

The media has become a bubble, disconnected from the suffering in the nation, hellbent on forcing its will. Will the people bend?
